review.title: Rule Based Expert System for Cerebral Palsy Diagnosis
review.abstract: The use of Artificial Intelligence is finding prominence not only in core computer areas, but also in cross disciplinary areas including medical diagnosis. In this paper, we present a rule based Expert System used in diagnosis of Cerebral Palsy. The expert system takes user input and depending on the symptoms of the patient, diagnoses if the patient is suffering from Cerebral Palsy. The Expert System also classifies the Cerebral Palsy as mild, moderate or severe based on the presented symptoms.

sections.text: Rule Based Expert System for Cerebral PalsyDiagnosis * Rajdeep BorgohainDepartment of Computer Science and Engineering, Dibrugarh University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Dibrugarh, AssamEmail: rajdeepgohain @ gmail.com Sugata SanyalSchool of Technology and Computer Science, Tata Ins Institte of Fundamental Research, Mumbai, India Email: sanyals @ gmail.com * Corresponding Author-----------------------------------------------------------ABSTRACT--------------------------------------------------------------------------The use of artificial intelligence is gaining importance not only in core areas of the computer, but also in cross-disciplinary areas including medical diagnosis. In this paper we present a rules-based expert system used in the diagnosis of cerebral palsy. The expert system accepts input from the user and, depending on the patient's symptoms, diagnoses when the patient suffers from cerebral palsy.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION1
sections.text: With the advent of the latest technologies in computer and information technology, the relationship between humans and computers has reached a new level. Computer science is not limited to core areas such as networks [7], network security [1, 4, 6], databases [2], but is also used in many interdisciplinary areas such as biology [12], chemistry [3], medical diagnostics [11], etc. In this paper, we present a rules-based expert system for diagnosing cerebral palsy and classify it as mild, severe or moderate according to the symptoms presented by users. Expert system is the ability to replicate people's thinking and reasoning based on some facts and rules. Expert systems have a place in various sectors such as drug diagnosis, decision support systems, education and tutoring systems used in medical diagnostics.

sections.heading: 2. CEREBRAL PALSY OVERVIEW
sections.text: Cerebral palsy is a non-progressive disease resulting from injuries in the foetal stage or in early childhood that results in postural, movement, gait and tonus deficits. Cerebral palsy restricts the patient's ability to perform full motor functions and restricts the patient's activities [15]. Statistics show that the number of children suffering from cerebral palsy varies between 1.5 and 4 per 1000 births. Cerebral palsy affects not only the state of health, but also economic conditions, since the medical costs for children with cerebral palsy are 10 times higher than for children without cerebral palsy or with other mental disabilities [5]. Depending on the symptoms of cerebral palsy, it can be classified as mild, moderate or severe. The primary symptoms of cerebral palsy are: 1 disease is not progressive. 2 Spasticity in patients without cerebral palsy or with other cognitive impairments of gait may be classified as mild, moderate or severe.

sections.heading: 4. METHODOLOGY FOR DIAGNOSIS
sections.text: Cerebral palsy is diagnosed on the basis of users "answers to questionnaires. In order to assess the disease, each symptom is assigned a specific weight [17] and on the basis of this weight, a definitive cumulative weight value is calculated on the basis of which the disease is diagnosed.

sections.heading: 4.1 ALGO RITHM FO R CUMULATIVE WEIGHTAGE SCORE
sections.text: The algorithm for calculating the weight value is: 1. The user of the system receives a questionnaire containing questions about the symptoms of the patient. The questions are asked in simple English without medical terminology for the convenience of the patient. The user of the system answers the questions with yes or no. A list of symptoms with the corresponding weight value is presented in Table 1. According to the user's input, each symptom is assigned the corresponding weight. For an affirmative answer, the weight is assigned as indicated in the table, while for a negative answer the weight value is assigned zero. 3. sections.heading: 5. EVALUATION OF THE SYS TEM
sections.text: The system showed accurate results when the specific symptoms of the test cases were given as user input. In addition, a number of parents who had already been diagnosed with cerebral palsy were asked for their input, and the system showed accurate results and diagnosed patients as having cerebral palsy and classified their illnesses accordingly.

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this article, we discussed the design and implementation of a rules-based expert system for cerebral palsy diagnosis, which helps to diagnose cerebral palsy and classify it as mild, moderate or severe. In implementing this system, we took into account the most classic symptoms of cerebral palsy and weighted each symptom according to user feedback. The expert system can do much to support the decision-making process of health professionals and also help parents who have children with cerebral palsy to assess their children and take appropriate measures to manage the disease.
